instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Hello,

I've received a board from an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>.
But actually the board is in a pretty bad condition..
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is shorted.

there is some big scratches in the board but I have the hope that it is fixable. Can someone help me?

Mac 1 is near UA550
Mac 2 is near CA903
Mac 3 is near <RESISTOR>R2724</RESISTOR>
Mac 4 is near <RESISTOR>R8171</RESISTOR>
Mac 5 is near QK092

your help will be really appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Board looks very ugly.
What is the exact ohm value to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Compare with all big coils; possibly short caused by a high-side MOSFET.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Thank you really much ! I appreciate it.

all measured to ground they are all between 0.4 and 0.5 ohms.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0.4 ohms to ground.
<CAPACITOR>C3502</CAPACITOR> = 0.4 ohms
<CAPACITOR>C3504</CAPACITOR> = 0.4 ohms
<CAPACITOR>C3503</CAPACITOR> = 0.5 ohms
<RESISTOR>R3461</RESISTOR>  = 0.5 ohms
<RESISTOR>R3451</RESISTOR>  = 0.5 ohms
<CAPACITOR>C5455</CAPACITOR> = 0.4 ohms
<CAPACITOR>C6456</CAPACITOR> = 0.5 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
That is really short.
I was waiting to see L7211/21/31, L7330 and L7410/20 resistance to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
My bad, I didn't understand, but here it is:
L7211        2.8 ohm 
L7231         infinite (1)
L7221        infinite (1)
L7330        19-20 ohm
L7410        5.5 ohm
L7420        5.6 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Should be safe to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> then; possibly shorted filter cap.
However, check first ohm value on other coils.

Start injecting 1V and slowly go up, if needed.
Set amp limit to max on lab PSU.

"L7211        2.8 ohm
L7231         infinite (1)
L7221        infinite (1)"
Are you really sure??
All are connected together, check schematic...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Hello, 

Thanks for your help, I've been able to find were the short could potentially be.

after verification big coils are not infinite but 2.8. 

I injected some voltage in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, and with isopropyl I found that <CAPACITOR>C9574</CAPACITOR> was getting really hot. So I changed the cap, and the problem was still the same... actually my power station wasn't allowing me to put more than 1,6v, and the cap was still over heating.  I found that <RESISTOR>R5630</RESISTOR> was the junction between  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD1_SNS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; and by removing <RESISTOR>R5630</RESISTOR> (was corroded), I'm able to inject more than 2v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I don't have any piece like this one so I'm going to buy it and replace it.

Do you think the problem for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted could come from there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
If a CPU power chip is shorted, very likely you've already fried the CPU.
Why don't you read related posts on the forum???
So many times I explained how NOT to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
I realise now that i’ve done some dumb things.
I’m new at this. Usually i was only repairing boards with CD32 burned. That’s the first one that i have to repair this way.
And i’m french, so i dont understand all in the forums topics.
I think that the cpu is fine. Because i ddnt put a lot of voltage in. And as i found all the broken components, i think that the cpu havnt been fried. They arent  related to cpu.

Btw thanks for your advice. I can only hope that the board can still be fixed (Hopefully it isnt for a customer).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
You MUST compare ohm value to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with all big coils, especially CPU ones.
An equal value can be sign of shorted high-side MOSFET connected to that coil.
This imply direct connection between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and coil.
If that coil is connected to CPU, where the injected voltage went?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
By measuring ohm to ground for all big coils I get
2.8 ohms for L7221 L7231 L7211
LA 340-640-650 3.7 ohms
LA 350 45 ohms
LA 300 82 ohms

As i understand, the problem could come from a high side mosfet connected to L7221-31-11. 
Could it be <RESISTOR>R7230</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7220</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R7210</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message: One of <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20/30 is shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Thank you really much, I was able to find the short.

L5199 is gone, and the trace too.. so I know that I need to make a jumper between <CAPACITOR>C5101</CAPACITOR> (1)  and J5100 pin 22. For <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> I think that I will have to do a really long jumper, but I don't know where to start and were to end?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
L5199 is before <CAPACITOR>C5100</CAPACITOR>/01.
You must bring <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL> to one of these caps.
I supposed to have continuity from these caps to J5100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
After bringing back continuity, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> came to 12v (with charger plugged). but the computer still don't wanna boot.
L7211/21/31 are all around 3.2 ohms.
Could the problem be repaired with dfu restore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
"I was able to find the short."
Which was the culprit, did you change it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message: The culprit was L5199 that was ripped of the board, <CAPACITOR>C5100</CAPACITOR>/01 were too, so I put back <CAPACITOR>C5100</CAPACITOR>/01 bc the trace wasn't gone. And I made a jumper to bring <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> to <CAPACITOR>C5100</CAPACITOR>. I also made a jumper between <CAPACITOR>C5100</CAPACITOR> and J5100.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
I have my doubts about that.
How can L5199 generate short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>???
It is connected to <SIGNAL>5V_G3S</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
I'm not sure, but the only other solution was that the short was created by <RESISTOR>R5630</RESISTOR>. And by removing it the short disappeared...
But actually the big coils are still the same resistance. Is that meaning that there is still a short? If yes, should I remove them 1 by 1 to find who is the culprit?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message: Do you mean <RESISTOR>R5630</RESISTOR> is removed now???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message: Yes, but i dont have another component  like that. So i will let this board for a moment. Thanks for your help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message:
Be sure no short on any pads of <RESISTOR>R5630</RESISTOR>.
I was thinking you've already found the bad CPU power supply chip (U72x0).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> bad board
threads.message: No problem, i’ll do updates when i can go further with this one.
